bioghist.head: Administrative/Biographical History
bioghist.p: Robert Harris was a commercial photographer active in South Africa; he maintained a studio in Port Elizabeth between 1880 and 1890. He published two photo books: Photographic views of Port Elizabeth and neighbourhood in 1876; and Photographic album of South African scenery sometime between 1880 and 1886. His album, South Africa: illustrated by a series of one hundred and four permanent photographs was published in Port Elizabeth in 1888. His photographs, which include views of urbanization in the developing cities and towns, and diamond mining in Kimberley, present an image of South Africa at a transformative moment for its economy and society. For additional information, see A.D. Bensusan, "19th century photographers in South Africa," Africana notes and news 15, no. 6 (1963): 219-252.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Album of large sepia albumen photographs of views of South African cities, and the islands of St. Helena and Madeira.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The town of Port Elizabeth, in East Cape, was a thriving port town, as seen in scenes of Jetty Street, leading to the harbor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Main Street is depicted, with its trolley tracks visible, and the lines of its imposing businesses and shops culminating in the City Hall building with its domed clock tower.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Included are scenes of the morning market--a cattle market offering pairs of yoked oxen, and vendors selling their wares from their wagons.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Depicts the indoor feather market and auction, where merchants examine and bid on ostrich and other types of exotic feathers laid out on long tables.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "The Hill" was the area above town where prosperous merchants built their country villas, an area of handsome houses and well-built churches, including the Hill Presbysterian Church at the right of the photograph.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "The Vlei" was a natural drainage point or reservoir, used to provide water for animals and clay for road construction. In 1883 the vlei was drained--probably as a response to the wealthy people who were moving into the area--and a decorative iron railing, visible in the photograph, was installed to beautify the area.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Depicts a view of the beach at North End, where spectators appear to be viewing a beach whale.

did.unittitle: "Red House," Zwartzkop's River - a boating station on the Swartzkops River

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In "Van Staadens Pass", a passage through the gorge of the Van Staadens River between Port Elizabeth and Humansdorp, three men stand beside a large wagon of wood drawn by a team of oxen.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Van Staadens area shows four members of a party of picnickers perched among the branches of a large baobab tree.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Cradock, where the photographer has captured the Cradock Bridge over the Fish River and another public building, possibly the Cradock municipal hall.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Depicts the high-steepled Dutch Reformed "Mother" Church (modeled after St Martin-in-the-Field Church in Trafalgar Square, London).
